channel.title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Jamaica Prepared a Financial Fortress for Disaster. Hurricane Melissa Will Test It.
item.description: All of Jamaica’s financial defenses — insurance, bonds and credit lines — could be deployed to recover from Hurricane Melissa. Will it be enough?

item.title: AI empowers criminals to launch ‘customized attacks at scale’—but could also help firms fortify their defenses, say tech industry leaders
item.description: Generative AI and more digital connections are opening up new avenues for cyberattacks.

item.title: A.I. Spending Is Accelerating Among Tech’s Biggest Companies
item.description: Despite the risk of a bubble, Google, Meta, Microsoft and Amazon plan to spend billions more on artificial intelligence than they already do.

item.title: The haunting consequences of ignoring tech debt in an agentic AI world
item.description: I'm Accenture's global cyber AI reinvention leader and the U.S. spends $1.52 trillion on tech debt, constantly fixing aging or clunky software. Now th...

item.title: If Elected, How Might Mamdani Use Mayoral Power in Ways That Affect Israel?
item.description: Zohran Mamdani’s opposition to Israel’s treatment of Palestinians could influence New York City’s investments, his appointees and city policing tactic...

item.title: The bloodbath in stocks was ‘the end of the cutting season,’ BofA says: Now we’re on alert for the ‘fail risks’ of 2025
item.description: No major central banks are expected to cut rates again this year, BofA predicts.

item.title: Meta’s $27 billion bet turns AI compute into Wall Street’s hottest new investment
item.description: As the AI data center build out charges ahead at full speed, a new asset class is emerging.

item.title: Goldman Sachs CEO: AI’s opportunity is enormous, but ‘there will be winners and losers’
item.description: David Solomon sees artificial intelligence as a major catalyst for U.S. economic growth—but warns that the path ahead won’t be a straight line.

item.title: A Legal Blizzard in Texas Targets Democrats and Promotes Ken Paxton
item.description: The Texas attorney general has escalated the pace of high-profile legal actions, raising concern that his Senate campaign is influencing his law enfor...

item.title: U.N. Human Rights Chief Says U.S. Attacks on Accused Drug Smugglers Are Illegal
item.description: The Trump administration’s military strikes on boats near South and Central America violate international law and must be investigated, a top official...

item.title: What’s Next for Andrew After He Loses ‘Prince’ Title?
item.description: King Charles III’s brother will retreat further from public life after additional damaging revelations about his ties to the sexual predator Jeffrey E...

item.title: Jamaica Prepared a Financial Fortress for Disaster. Hurricane Melissa Will Test It.
item.description: All of Jamaica’s financial defenses — insurance, bonds and credit lines — could be deployed to recover from Hurricane Melissa. Will it be enough?

item.title: Prince Andrew Is Losing His Titles and His Home
item.description: King Charles III’s younger brother, who fell from grace over his association with Jeffrey Epstein, will no longer be able to call himself a prince. Th...

item.title: Coal Jobs or Climate? Trump’s Push Revives a Debate on the Navajo Nation.
item.description: As the economic engine for the region, coal offered solid work. But it has also used up water, polluted the air and raised health concerns.

item.title: Low Prices Aren’t Stopping Exxon and Chevron From Pumping More Oil
item.description: The two biggest U.S. oil companies increased production in the third quarter and reported lower but still robust profits.
